EU.content: for Schelling, thinking as Einbildungskraft, as post-Kantian originary unity > all differences translations of same > post-critical, critique of critique
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, thinking as Einbildungskraft, as post-Kantian originary unity > all differences translations of same > post-critical, critique of critique

EU.content: originary unity precedes opposition sensible/intelligible, math resembles philosophy, math belongs to world of reflected image > analogical translation btwn philosophy/math assured by symbol (Bild) > symbolicity developed in play of Abbildung, Einbildung
EU.linkedContent: originary unity precedes opposition sensible/intelligible, math resembles philosophy, math belongs to world of reflected image > analogical translation btwn philosophy/math assured by symbol (Bild) > symbolicity developed in play of Abbildung, Einbildung

EU.content: for Schelling, poetry at heart of philosophy, poem is a philosopheme
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, poetry at heart of philosophy, poem is a philosopheme

EU.content: for Schelling, reason & imagination one & same thing in Einbildungskraft (not Latinate Imagination, which is false fantasy) > one in the real [imagination, art], one in the ideal [reason would have to be ideal] > intertranslatability of rational & fantastic only amazing from standpoint of understanding [Hegel makes analogous move]
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, reason & imagination one & same thing in Einbildungskraft (not Latinate Imagination, which is false fantasy) > one in the real [imagination, art], one in the ideal [reason would have to be ideal] > intertranslatability of rational & fantastic only amazing from standpoint of understanding [Hegel makes analogous move]

EU.content: In-Eins-Bildung (uni-formation) > paradox: concept of fundamental translatability linked poetically to a natural language [German] that resists translation
EU.linkedContent: In-Eins-Bildung (uni-formation) > paradox: concept of fundamental translatability linked poetically to a natural language [German] that resists translation

EU.content: but this confirms Schelling’s thesis: uni-forme sans uniformiser > preserves universal & particular in imprint it produces
EU.linkedContent: but this confirms Schelling’s thesis: uni-forme sans uniformiser > preserves universal & particular in imprint it produces

EU.content: In-Eins-Bildung: disseminates in profusion, its emanation (Ausfluss) traverses world of phenomena via reason & imagination
EU.linkedContent: In-Eins-Bildung: disseminates in profusion, its emanation (Ausfluss) traverses world of phenomena via reason & imagination

EU.content: university must also be thought in logic of uni-formation > poetics of translation
EU.linkedContent: university must also be thought in logic of uni-formation > poetics of translation

EU.content: Schelling, Nietzsche, Heidegger against ends, professionalization of philosophy
EU.linkedContent: Schelling, Nietzsche, Heidegger against ends, professionalization of philosophy

EU.content: acc. Schelling, every “new” philosophy makes a new “step (pas)” in form, poetic originality, a provocation/challenge to translation
EU.linkedContent: acc. Schelling, every “new” philosophy makes a new “step (pas)” in form, poetic originality, a provocation/challenge to translation

EU.content: Schelling’s originality: philosophy must possess formal originality (it’s a work of art)
EU.linkedContent: Schelling’s originality: philosophy must possess formal originality (it’s a work of art)

EU.content: for Schelling, math is different from philosophy: the latter provokes/challenges translation, whereas math solves or annuls translation problems
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, math is different from philosophy: the latter provokes/challenges translation, whereas math solves or annuls translation problems

EU.content: philosophers are capable of Wechsel der Formen [Derrida describes PC as Weschsel der Tönen], an Über-setzung that posits novelty while ensuring passage beyond differential particularity
EU.linkedContent: philosophers are capable of Wechsel der Formen [Derrida describes PC as Weschsel der Tönen], an Über-setzung that posits novelty while ensuring passage beyond differential particularity

EU.content: [vis-à-vis Schelling] can philosophy be acquired? is it innate? a free gift (ein freies Geschenk)? an art requiring genius of natural language?
EU.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Schelling] can philosophy be acquired? is it innate? a free gift (ein freies Geschenk)? an art requiring genius of natural language?

EU.content: even if gift, must possess w/ practice
EU.linkedContent: even if gift, must possess w/ practice

EU.content: person w/out intuition can’t understand at all—no passageway
EU.linkedContent: person w/out intuition can’t understand at all—no passageway

EU.content: for Schelling, philosopher develops negative condition: consciousness of inanity of all finite knowledge > ability to translate, re-translate, the real to the ideal can be acquired—can be cultivated in a Bildung and become untransformable habitus, unalterable organ
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, philosopher develops negative condition: consciousness of inanity of all finite knowledge > ability to translate, re-translate, the real to the ideal can be acquired—can be cultivated in a Bildung and become untransformable habitus, unalterable organ

EU.content: acc. Schelling, Kant makes philosophy finite [but Derrida says there are 2x2 Kants]
EU.linkedContent: acc. Schelling, Kant makes philosophy finite [but Derrida says there are 2x2 Kants]

EU.content: Schelling: philosophy becomes truly objective only in art > an art of generalized translation
EU.linkedContent: Schelling: philosophy becomes truly objective only in art > an art of generalized translation

EU.content: Schelling: both poetry/philosophy require self-produced original image (Bild) of world
EU.linkedContent: Schelling: both poetry/philosophy require self-produced original image (Bild) of world

EU.content: [vis-à-vis Schelling] art can never be limited/programmed by State, there is no State culture > philosophy, which demands unconditional freedom, should reside in Faculty of Arts
EU.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Schelling] art can never be limited/programmed by State, there is no State culture > philosophy, which demands unconditional freedom, should reside in Faculty of Arts

EU.content: bureaucratic organization doesn’t provide for philosophy, has ceased being a free association in view of the arts (poetic translation)
EU.linkedContent: bureaucratic organization doesn’t provide for philosophy, has ceased being a free association in view of the arts (poetic translation)

EU.content: though CIPH is Schellingian as a place reserved for problematic of translation, it has an anti-Schellingian angle: State can recover all its power if uni-formation is blindly trusted
EU.linkedContent: though CIPH is Schellingian as a place reserved for problematic of translation, it has an anti-Schellingian angle: State can recover all its power if uni-formation is blindly trusted

EU.content: Schelling against Kant’s separation of Wissen and Handeln (action); there is “but one world,” no world in itself; philosophy is ethics > duality of languages not annulled but derived from result of reflection
EU.linkedContent: Schelling against Kant’s separation of Wissen and Handeln (action); there is “but one world,” no world in itself; philosophy is ethics > duality of languages not annulled but derived from result of reflection

EU.content: Kant’s The Conflict of the Faculties constructed on “untranslatable multiplicity of languages,” dissociations of a discursive type: performative/constative, public/private, spirit/letter etc.
EU.linkedContent: Kant’s The Conflict of the Faculties constructed on “untranslatable multiplicity of languages,” dissociations of a discursive type: performative/constative, public/private, spirit/letter etc.

EU.content: for Schelling, ethics (raised to a point beyond determination) makes us similar to God, onto-theological translation w/out rupture > a risk of totalizing absolutization of State (which Kant would deem dangerous)
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, ethics (raised to a point beyond determination) makes us similar to God, onto-theological translation w/out rupture > a risk of totalizing absolutization of State (which Kant would deem dangerous)

EU.content: Kant’s (not unconditional) liberalism would caution against crossing certain limits, so as to avoid total absolutization of State
EU.linkedContent: Kant’s (not unconditional) liberalism would caution against crossing certain limits, so as to avoid total absolutization of State

EU.content: for Schelling, State is philosophy/action > standpoint of Ur-wissen
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, State is philosophy/action > standpoint of Ur-wissen

EU.content: Schelling’s unity of ideal & real in originary knowledge: speak w/out trope, no metaphor (also nothing but metaphor): a generalized rhetoric [generalized fetishism] or translatology
EU.linkedContent: Schelling’s unity of ideal & real in originary knowledge: speak w/out trope, no metaphor (also nothing but metaphor): a generalized rhetoric [generalized fetishism] or translatology

EU.content: [re: use of word “translation” to refer to “transposition, transfer, transport” in a sense not strictly linguistic] for Schelling, language is a living phenomenon; Novalis, Goethe: nature an author to be translated w/ skill of a philologist
EU.linkedContent: [re: use of word “translation” to refer to “transposition, transfer, transport” in a sense not strictly linguistic] for Schelling, language is a living phenomenon; Novalis, Goethe: nature an author to be translated w/ skill of a philologist

EU.content: Schelling: “nature is like some very ancient author whose message is written in hieroglyphics on colossal pages” [geologic?]
EU.linkedContent: Schelling: “nature is like some very ancient author whose message is written in hieroglyphics on colossal pages” [geologic?]

EU.content: for Schelling, individuals, who are finite, must translate > if mind could simply be infinite, there’d be no need to translate > “originary knowledge” can become “real" in an individual, only in der Gattung (in the genus), i.e. in historical institutions > history: becoming-real of idea
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, individuals, who are finite, must translate > if mind could simply be infinite, there’d be no need to translate > “originary knowledge” can become “real" in an individual, only in der Gattung (in the genus), i.e. in historical institutions > history: becoming-real of idea

EU.content: Schelling describes damage of professionalization, he issues imperative that universities give instruction in methods/aims of academic study, as a whole & in particular
EU.linkedContent: Schelling describes damage of professionalization, he issues imperative that universities give instruction in methods/aims of academic study, as a whole & in particular

EU.content: for Schelling, those whose thought isn’t regulated by living and buzzing communion w/ divine [w/ community] are like sexless bees (geschlechtslose Bienen) > depositing inorganic excrement outside hive—proof of their platitudes
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, those whose thought isn’t regulated by living and buzzing communion w/ divine [w/ community] are like sexless bees (geschlechtslose Bienen) > depositing inorganic excrement outside hive—proof of their platitudes

EU.content: for Schelling, man is tasked w/ supplementing, complementing, the world’s manifestation (eine Ergänzung der Welterscheinung) > develop God’s revelation, which is lacking: this is called translation, it is the destination of the university
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, man is tasked w/ supplementing, complementing, the world’s manifestation (eine Ergänzung der Welterscheinung) > develop God’s revelation, which is lacking: this is called translation, it is the destination of the university
